awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG:JST: Green Mobility for Aging Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Transportation is crucial to seniors being able to access needed services and maintain overall independence. Rural seniors, particularly, may not always have ready access to good transportation options, and they are often required to travel longer or further to access critical services such as hospitals, medical and dental care, and supermarkets. Some seniors may also be exposed to increased crash risk which can lead to shifts in driving patterns and habits that can limit overall mobility. These problems are not exclusive to seniors in the United States. For that reason, the research team has partnered with colleagues at Nagoya University in Japan, with the goal of examining the needs of seniors, particularly those living in rural areas in both Japan and the United States, which could benefit from current as well as near future vehicle automation features. The goal for these automated vehicle features would be to mitigate the effects of the aforementioned issues by seamlessly aiding rural seniors in their driving tasks, especially in negotiating the traffic scenarios and conditions that may have become increasingly troublesome for them. The Japan and United States project teams will explore similar aspects of this problem, recognizing and adapting to cultural and societal differences between the two countries.
 
The proposed work will advance knowledge in two main areas. First, how could vehicle automation that is environmentally friendly, assistive, and adaptive be helpful to senior drivers, particularly those living in rural areas? System requirements with empirical bases can then emerge from this knowledge to provide a foundation for associated social work and community engagement. Second, what technological advancements will be necessary to develop these driver-assistive systems? The knowledge emerging from such an understanding could be used to emphasize and/or incentivize development in the areas found to be most crucial for these individuals, who may be vulnerable in several ways (i.e., due to age-related disability, lack of sound transportation infrastructure, and socio-economic status). In undertaking these research goals, the team will use a community-based participatory research approach and leverage its strong partnerships with vehicle manufacturers, automated system providers, senior citizen advocates, deployment communities (e.g., senior-living centers), and consumers. 

The proposed systems are expected to have significant impacts on the mobility of senior drivers by allowing the retention of mobility and independence for longer than is possible with current vehicles. A general understanding of the usefulness and technological state of these systems will afford an empirical basis to solicit support from industry partners for further human-centered development and deployment of the identified technologies in support of this transportation-impoverished subset of our population.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

While the rate of traffic fatalities for seniors over the age of 65 decreased from 1999 to 2008, data from 2009 to 2018 fail to show any further reduction in fatalities (National Safety Council, 2020). To reduce their traffic-related risks, senior drivers often self-restrict their driving or avoid intimidating driving situations. Unfortunately, such self-restriction may negatively affect their mobility.

Research indicates that reductions in physical strength and perception may be responsible for the increased traffic risk experienced by seniors (Marshall, 2008; Morgan and King, 1995). Older drivers may struggle to negotiate certain roadway scenarios and even stop driving altogether. Particularly for seniors in rural areas, this can lead to increased isolation, which adversely affects health. Thus, improving mobility for rural seniors has the potential to reduce social isolation and improve overall health and well-being (Coyle and Dugan, 2012). One potential solution, advanced technologies such as automated vehicles, may be able to improve rural senior mobility, but these technologies must coexist with and complement existing options. In addition, they must ease any negative perceptions that seniors may have regarding safety, utility, and performance.

Methods

The Roanoke, Virginia, area was the focus of this study. Roanoke has a small urban core that quickly transitions into a rural landscape. Rural older adults may have to commute up to 45 minutes on single-lane roadways to reach the city center (Figure 1). Data were collected from (1) interviews with stakeholders and front-line workers in mobility, and (2) a questionnaire administered to rural seniors themselves. Twelve interviews were completed with stakeholders, and 40 questionnaires were completed by rural seniors. Together, the interviews and questionnaires provided insight into options and barriers to the use of alternative transportation by rural seniors.

Results

The Roanoke Valley area has several mobility options for seniors who live in or near the urban core. However, many of these services are limited to specific destinations, such as pharmacies or hospitals, or only available to riders who meet strict criteria (for example, those over the age of 65 who do not drive at all). For seniors living outside the urban core, very few options exist. The options that do exist are often too costly given the sparse population and long travel distances required (Figure 2).

Stakeholder interviewers identified many barriers to mobility for rural seniors, including limited options outside the city center, long wait times, lack of timeliness and reliability, and lack of infrastructure such as sidewalks, bus stops, or bus shelters. Jurisdictional restrictions also prevent services from readily crossing political boundaries. Cultural beliefs may also deter residents from trusting government programs. Finally, a lack of awareness of the available options was commonly noted, along with a lack of coordination across stakeholders.

The seniors themselves listed several barriers to transportation, including a lack of availability, difficulty of scheduling, and high cost. In general, seniors rely on friends or family, a public bus, or walking as options when unable to drive themselves. Seniors expressed a clear preference for a safety attendant to be present in any service that might rely on an autonomous vehicle. Additionally, most seniors make use of a local community center for socialization. Thus, community centers would be key locations to focus on when  developing new transportation offerings.

Discussion

Results generally suggest that rural seniors are willing to consider advanced technologies to improve mobility. However, these solutions need to be developed with an understanding of existing barriers and current transportation services. It is essential to integrate existing and new services into tools that transcend jurisdictions and allow rural seniors to make informed choices that improve their mobility. New services can range from senior-friendly user interfaces to automated shuttles that travel between commonly accessed locations and rural homes. One potential model is the Danish company, FlexDanmark, which offers an easy-to-use software application that connects many public and private mobility options in Denmark.

Better mobility for rural seniors not only improves access to typical necessities such as grocery stores or pharmacies. It also has a direct impact on quality of life by reducing social isolation and increasing opportunities for social interaction. As part of the outreach component of this study, the lessons learned from this research will be passed on to stakeholders to help them develop more innovative solutions to senior mobility. Future work by the project team will focus on pilot deployments of advanced technologies.

References

Coyle, C. E., & Dugan, E. (2012). Social isolation, loneliness and health among older adults. Journal of Aging and Health, 24(8), 1346-1363.

Marshall, S. C. (2008). The role of reduced fitness to drive due to medical impairments in explaining crashes involving older drivers. Traffic Injury Prevention, 9(4), 291-298.

Morgan, R., & King, D. (1995). The older driver ? A review. Postgraduate Medical Journal, 71, 525-528

National Safety Council (2020). Injury facts ? Older drivers. https://injuryfacts.nsc.org/motor-vehicle/road-users/older-drivers/
